thread.title: ‘Would introducing a sugar tax change behaviour? Absolutely’
thread.title_full: ‘Would introducing a sugar tax change behaviour? Absolutely’

title: ‘Would introducing a sugar tax change behaviour? Absolutely’
text:
1 of 1 Stephen Dorrell is back in the political limelight as chairman of the NHS Confederation Richard Pohle/The Times Rachel Sylvester and Alice Thomson Published at 12:01AM, October 24 2015 David Cameron’s first term as PM was a wasted opportunity for the NHS, says Stephen Dorrell, a Tory former health secretary 
The NHS is in crisis. Waiting lists are rising, junior doctors are protesting, hospitals are deep in debt — and it’s not even winter yet. For David Cameron, who once said that his priorities could be summed up by three letters, N-H-S, health threatens to be a political disaster too. This week a row erupted over proposals for a sugar tax, with the government accused of suppressing a report by public health officials that backed the plan as a way of tackling obesity. 
Stephen Dorrell, health secretary in the 1990s, has seen it all before but now he is back on Subscribe now
